author: By Melina Delkic
title: ‘We’re not going to risk their lives’: A Florida school board defies the governor’s masking ban.
description: After Broward County officials voted to impose a mask mandate, Gov. Ron DeSantis threatened to revoke their pay.
content: The chairwoman of the Broward County School Board in Florida said on Sunday that the district had no choice but to defy Gov. Ron DeSantis’s ban on mask mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Misjudging the Pace of Taliban Sweep
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 15, 2021.
content: “The puzzle for me is the absence of contingency planning: If everyone knew we were headed for the exits, why did we not have a plan over the past two years for making this work?”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kabul falls to the Taliban as the Afghan government collapses and the president flees.
description: The insurgents’ conquest of the country is all but complete, and prominent politicians are talking with the Taliban about a transfer of power.
content: The Taliban effectively sealed their control of Afghanistan on Sunday, pouring into the capital, Kabul, and meeting little resistance as President Ashraf Ghani fled the country, the government collapsed, and chaos and fear gripped the city, with tens of thousands of people trying to escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Blinken says the Taliban moved faster than expected, but defends removal of U.S. troops.
description: The secretary of state forcefully defended the decision to withdraw the American military from Afghanistan, citing threats to the United States if it reneged on a peace deal.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Sunday that the defeat of Afghan security forces that has led to the Taliban’s takeover “happened more quickly than we anticipated,” although he maintained the Biden administration’s position that keeping U.S. troops in Afghanistan was not in American interests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: In Washington, Recriminations Over Afghanistan Emerge Quickly
description: President Biden is finding few outspoken defenders amid the chaotic collapse of the Afghan government. But after 20 years, a war-weary America may still give the president a pass.
content: WASHINGTON — A conference call between members of Congress and the Biden administration’s top diplomatic and military leaders on Afghanistan turned contentious on Sunday, as lawmakers pressed the administration on how intelligence could have failed so badly and how long the military would help hold the Kabul airport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: In Backlash to Racial Reckoning, Conservative Publishers See Gold
description: Books on race and antiracism have sold well over the past year. Now titles like “I Can’t Breathe: How a Racial Hoax Is Killing America” and “Race Crazy” are coming.
content: The book “How to Be an Antiracist,” by Ibram X. Kendi, has sold almost 2 million printed copies, e-books and audiobooks since it came out two years ago, according to its publisher, an astonishing sales figure more commonly associated with books about Donald Trump than titles on difficult social issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: For Biden, Images of Defeat He Wanted to Avoid
description: President Biden will go down in history, fairly or unfairly, as the president who presided over a humiliating final act in the American experiment in Afghanistan.
content: Rarely in modern presidential history have words come back to bite an American commander in chief as swiftly as these from President Biden a little more than five weeks ago: “There’s going to be no circumstance where you see people being lifted off the roof of an embassy of the United States in Afghanistan.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Flash Floods in Turkey Kill 59, and Dozens Are Still Missing
description: The death toll rose to at least 59 a fifth day after the disaster, and more than 70 people remain missing.
content: The death toll in the flash floods that roared across northern Turkey has risen to 59, with dozens of people still missing and many villages still cut off, almost a week after the disaster first struck, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: It Was a Terrifying Census for White Nationalists
description: The white power acolytes saw this train approaching from a distance, and they did everything they could to head it off.
content: For some of us, the census data released on Thursday was fascinating. For others, it was, I would presume, downright frightening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Tragedy of Afghanistan
description: The war had to end. But it didn’t have to end in such chaos.
content: The rapid reconquest of the capital, Kabul, by the Taliban after two decades of a staggeringly expensive, bloody effort to establish a secular government with functioning security forces in Afghanistan is, above all, unutterably tragic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: A Big Step for Infrastructure Spending
description: The next step for the $1 trillion bipartisan bill is the House. And its future there is not guaranteed.
content: The Senate approved a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill to rebuild roads and bridges and to fund broadband and climate resilience initiatives. The legislation includes several measures to help pay for it, including repurposing pandemic relief funds and tougher scrutiny of cryptocurrency transactions (though the Congressional Budget Office said the plan would still add $256 billion to the deficit over the next decade). Shortly after the passage of the infrastructure bill, the Senate voted along party lines to pass a $3.5 trillion budget blueprint to expand the social safety net, which would be funded primarily by higher taxes for the wealthy and corporations. Both measures face an arduous path in the House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. Fox
title: Michael J. Fox Reviews a Thoughtful Memoir on the Challenges of Living With Disability
description: In “I Live a Life Like Yours,” Jan Grue, a Norwegian professor, writes of living with a rare form of spinal muscular atrophy.
content: I LIVE A LIFE LIKE YOURSA MemoirBy Jan GrueTranslated by B.L. Crook
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Michael Thomas, Writer and Bête Noire of the Moneyed Class, Dies at 85
description: His early careers as an art historian and Wall Street financier informed his financial thrillers, which often savaged the rich and powerful.
content: Michael M. Thomas, an acerbic columnist and novelist who wrote chiefly about money and how people got it, what they did with it and what it did to them — people he dismissed as “social climbers, stock market papermongers, real estate shills and assorted other virtuosos of hype and blather” — died on Aug. 7 in Brooklyn. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Beginner’s Luck? A Stunning No-Hitter in a Year Full of Them.
description: In his first career start, Tyler Gilbert of the Diamondbacks threw M.L.B.’s eighth no-hitter of the year. There haven’t been that many in a single season since 1884.
content: In the early days of baseball, the sport was mostly a test of hitting, fielding and base running. The pitcher was merely the fielder in the middle of the diamond who tossed the ball underhand — as if pitching a horseshoe — to home plate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Trudeau Calls Early Election in Canada
description: The prime minister hopes his handling of the pandemic will help his Liberal Party win a majority in the House of Commons. Opponents say voting amid a Covid surge is dangerous.
content: OTTAWA — Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Sunday announced an early election in Canada, a step he said was needed to give his government a mandate for dealing with the pandemic and the recovery from its economic effects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: ‘The Threepenny Opera’ Returns Home, Liberated
description: Barrie Kosky’s new production for the Berliner Ensemble, at the theater where the famous work premiered, knows where to break the rules.
content: BERLIN — “I’m not asking for an opera here,” the notorious criminal Macheath says at his wedding, early in a work that happens to be called “Die Dreigroschenoper” (“The Threepenny Opera”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Candace Jackson
title: The U.S. real estate market begins to cool after bump from the pandemic.
description: The pandemic created a frenzied real estate market in much of the United States that has yet to let up, with demand for housing still outpacing the number of homes coming on the market, giving sellers a heavy upper hand in most of the country. But economists say the market cooled off a bit in July — perhaps a sign that the wild price appreciations of the past year may have scared off some buyers who prefer to wait until things calm down, to stay put or to continue renting.
content: The pandemic created a frenzied real estate market in much of the United States that has yet to let up, with demand for housing still outpacing the number of homes coming on the market, giving sellers a heavy upper hand in most of the country. But economists say the market cooled off a bit in July — perhaps a sign that the wild price appreciations of the past year may have scared off some buyers who prefer to wait until things calm down, to stay put or to continue renting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Stick-to-itiveness
description: Freddie Cheng strikes a chord.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — One of the most important personal qualities a new solver can have is stick-to-itiveness. Getting started in crossword puzzles is hard — it can feel like learning a new language as you figure out how to decipher the subtle hints in the clues that tell you what to look for in an entry. For example, a new solver may not know what “, say” means, or that an abbreviation in the clue means there will be an abbreviation in the entry. The more you solve, the more you begin to recognize these little flags, but getting over that initial hump of “why on earth is there a question mark in this clue?!” can feel insurmountable.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Evacuation from Kabul falters as chaos at airport reigns.
description: The U.S. embassy warned citizens to not head to the airport after reports of gunfire and said the situation is “changing quickly.”
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The U.S. embassy warned Americans not to head to the airport in Kabul because of a situation that was “changing quickly” after the Taliban entered the city on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: You’ve Never Heard of the Biggest Digital Media Company in America
description: Red Ventures has turned very specific advice into very big business.
content: INDIAN LAND, S.C. — Lindsey Turrentine first heard of Red Ventures last fall, when it bought the venerable tech news site CNET, where she is the senior vice president in charge of content. She sat down at her kitchen table in Berkeley, Calif., and frantically started Googling to find out what it was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall, Christina Goldbaum, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Ruhullah Khapalwak
title: In an Overrun Kabul, Many Have No Place to Run
description: Afghanistan’s capital fell to the Taliban far faster than many had imagined it would, leaving most Afghans with no way out.
content: The citizens of Kabul were given reassurances that they would be safe, that a deal had been struck to avoid a full-fledged attack by the Taliban on their city. But for many Afghans, the scenes playing out around them on Sunday in their capital told another story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May
title: ‘Our Hands and Feet Are Tied’: Hong Kong’s Opposition Quits in Droves
description: The landslide victory of pro-democracy politicians in local elections in 2019 was a stunning rebuke of Beijing. Now, fear of retaliation has driven them to quit.
content: HONG KONG — When Hong Kong’s pro-democracy politicians won a resounding victory in local council elections in 2019, they inspired hopes of democratic change. Now, fears of arrest have driven most of them to quit, laying bare that dream’s dramatic collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Afghanistan, Haiti, ‘Jeopardy!’: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Roger Federer Faces Knee Surgery, Putting His Future in Doubt
description: The 20-time Grand Slam champion will miss the U.S. Open and undergo his fourth knee surgery since 2016. He will be on crutches and off the tennis court “for many months.”
content: There will be no U.S. Open for Roger Federer this year, and after his announcement on Sunday that he will have yet another knee operation, it is time to question whether he will play tennis on tour again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib
title: ‘I’m the Only Surgeon’: After Haiti Quake, Thousands Seek Scarce Care
description: A day after a magnitude-7.2 earthquake killed an estimated 1,300 people in western Haiti, the country, already suffering from a dire lack of doctors, struggled to help the many wounded.
content: LES CAYES, Haiti — With broken bones and open wounds, the injured jammed into damaged hospitals or headed to the airport, hoping for mercy flights out. A handful of doctors toiled all night in makeshift triage wards. A retired senator used his seven-seat propeller plane to ferry the most urgent patients to emergency care in the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: As City Reopens, Performers Try to Uplift New York’s State of Mind
description: Some of the city’s most recognizable entertainers take turns singing, dancing and playing instruments in a new music video covering Billy Joel’s 1976 song.
content: As New York awakens from its slumber, it’s clear this isn’t just any morning. There’s Stephen Colbert, emerging onto a rooftop, and Peppermint, a drag performer, strolling on a bridge in glittering heels. On the Lower East Side, Sara Bareilles is sitting in a cafe, but she has something on her mind, so she’s not touching her lox bagel.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘We Came Up to a Man Who Was Selling Bouquets of Flowers’
description: A traffic-jam surprise, saving a seat on the A train and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Alexandra E. Petri
title: Tropical Depression Grace heads toward quake-ravaged Haiti.
description: The tropical depression is expected to batter Haiti late Monday or early Tuesday.
content: As people in Haiti desperately search for survivors from a devastating earthquake, the threat of yet another natural disaster looms over the island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Neil Vigdor
title: Thousands Evacuate as Wildfires Ravage Utah and Northern California
description: Firefighters battled the Dixie Fire in California and a new fire in Parleys Canyon in Utah as searing temperatures continued to bake the western United States.
content: As intense wildfires continued to burn across parts of the western United States on Sunday, prompting thousands of evacuations in Utah and Northern California, firefighters in Oregon announced on Sunday that they had fully contained what had once been the country’s largest wildfire this year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 15, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 15, 2021.
content: An article on Page 6 this weekend about David Lat, one of the first patients to be put on a ventilator while hospitalized with Covid-19, misspells the surname of Mr. Lat’s husband. He is Zach Shemtob, not Shamtob.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Lara Jakes
title: Rushed Evacuation in Kabul Highlights Disconnect in Washington
description: Pentagon officials had warned the White House about delaying a drawdown or full evacuation of American personnel from Afghanistan.
content: WASHINGTON — There was gunfire at the airport and a dire warning from the State Department to shelter in place as the United States began the frantic evacuations of Americans and Afghan allies from the Afghan capital, Kabul, after it fell to the Taliban in one harrowing weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Glimmerglass Creates Magic in Its Own Backyard
description: The pandemic forced the company outdoors and to trim staples by Verdi and Mozart. Our critic found the experience to be ripe with potential for drawing in new audiences.
content: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — The Glimmerglass Festival has long boasted two features that made it a magnet for opera lovers during summer seasons: A bucolic setting in upstate New York, and the acoustically splendid, ideally intimate Alice Busch Opera Theater, which has a sizable stage and just 914 seats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ethan Hauser
title: The Texas State Supreme Court upholds governor’s mask mandate ban, for now.
description: The decision is temporary because the State Supreme Court must make a final ruling.
content: The Texas governor can ban mask mandates, at least for now, after the State Supreme Court on Sunday granted the state’s request for an emergency stay of an appellate court ruling that would have allowed mandatory face coverings in schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The Taliban take Afghanistan.
content: The government collapsed on Sunday after President Ashraf Ghani fled for Uzbekistan with his wife. Here are live updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Cleveland Browns G.M. Talks the ‘Thrill’ of Turning the Team Around
description: Andrew Berry became the N.F.L.’s youngest-ever general manager at 32 last year. But his challenge is as old as the sport itself: finding a way to win.
content: For most of the last two decades, the Cleveland Browns exemplified what it meant to be an N.F.L. bottom feeder.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘I Write About the Law. But Could I Really Help Free a Prisoner?’
description: For years, a journalist covered attempts to exonerate incarcerated people. But a letter from an inmate in a Louisiana prison led to a different kind of story.
content: In 2019, Emily Bazelon, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine, began communicating with Yutico Briley, an inmate at a prison in Jackson, La.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Michael Crowley
title: Taliban Takeover Could Extinguish U.S. Influence in Kabul
description: After 20 years of diplomacy and support, American officials are now contemplating the harrowing question of whether — and how — they might engage with a Taliban government in Afghanistan.
content: WASHINGTON — The fall of Kabul on Sunday left the Biden administration facing the once-unthinkable prospect of whether, and how, to engage with a Taliban-led government in Afghanistan’s capital — or cede all influence in the country to an extremist group that brutalized Afghans and harbored Osama bin Laden as he planned attacks on America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
title: Officials in Washington are scrambling to keep up with the fast-moving events in Afghanistan.
description: Confusion reigned in Washington early Sunday as the Taliban entered Kabul, Afghanistan’s capital, with U.S. officials scrambling to determine  how safe Americans still there would be.
content: Confusion reigned in Washington early Sunday as the Taliban entered Kabul, Afghanistan’s capital, with U.S. officials scrambling to determine  how safe Americans still there would be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: Making S’mores Around the Campfire at the Apocalypse
description: In “The Grown-Ups,” a play by Skylar Fox and Simon Henriques, audience members sit around a real fire in a backyard in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.
content: In the light of the campfire on a summer night, after the children have gone to bed, some of the grown-ups sit up and talk. Most of them have been coming here since they were small, and when they roast marshmallows for s’mores, the scent must take them right back — the charred-sugar sweetness that means, yep, someone’s marshmallow is suddenly aflame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein and Tariro Mzezewa
title: Doubts, Anger and Anxiety: What It’s Like to Go to School Now
description: What was supposed to be a new, relatively normal year has become a politicized, bewildering experience for many parents, students and educators.
content: It was supposed to be a new school year, a fresh start with relative normalcy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Fremson and Kirk Johnson
title: Teaching a New Generation of Balloonists to Go Up, Up and Away
description: Ballooning had its heyday in the 70s. A new program in Washington State aims to introduce the aging sport to a new — and more diverse — class of aeronauts.
content: ENUMCLAW, Wash. — Three thousand feet up, just after dawn on a recent morning, McKenna Secrist reached over the rim of a metal-framed wicker gondola and released a handful of popcorn to test the wind. Instead of drifting down with gravity, the little white kernels lofted up, up and away, revealing the flow of air, and the descent rate of her balloon as she prepared to land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: Biden Administration Prompts Largest Permanent Increase in Food Stamps
description: The jump in benefits, the biggest in the program’s history, comes after a revision of the initiative’s nutrition standards that supporters say will reduce hunger and better reflect how Americans eat.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration has revised the nutrition standards of the food stamp program and prompted the largest permanent increase to benefits in the program’s history, a move that will give poor people more power to fill their grocery carts but add billions of dollars to the cost of a program that feeds one in eight Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: They Tried to Beat DiMaggio. Like Everyone Else, They Failed.
description: In M.L.B.’s Beat the Streak game, fans build virtual lineups in hopes of topping Joe DiMaggio’s 56-game hitting streak. After 20 years, no one has won.
content: Roberto Aguirre-Hunn Jr., a chef in East Lansing, Mich., was just six picks away from assembling a virtual hitting streak that would have netted him $5.6 million in 2019. But he chose D.J. LeMahieu to extend his streak to 52, and LeMahieu went 0 for 4, leaving Aguirre-Hunn in tears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: The Security Council set an emergency meeting on Afghanistan.
description: It remains unclear how the U.N. will regard the Taliban if they declare themselves the legitimate power in Afghanistan.
content: The United Nations Security Council scheduled an emergency meeting for Monday morning after the Taliban appeared to take control of Afghanistan, where the U.N. has maintained an extensive aid operation since the early days of the American-led occupation two decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Can a Covid Mask Protect Me From Wildfire Smoke?
description: Here’s what we know about wildfire smoke and a few tips to protect yourself.
content: As the Dixie Fire rages in California, plumes of noxious smoke have turned the air as far afield as Salt Lake City and Denver into some of the dirtiest in the world. Fires across western Canada and the Pacific Northwest last month turned the sun red as far away as New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By César Muñoz Acebes
title: From Rio, a Cautionary Tale on Police Violence
description: Excessive use of force is common in Brazil, and most of the targets of that violence are Black youths in the favelas.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — In 2015, Adriana Perez da Silva’s 16-year-old son and four of his friends were driving home after a day in the park when the police fired at their car, killing them. Ms. Silva believes they were targeted because they were Black. As a researcher of police abuses in Latin America at Human Rights Watch, I have interviewed many survivors and relatives of victims. But her interview has stayed with me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Afghans working for U.S. government broadcasters fear Taliban backlash.
description: The Afghans working for the U.S. government broadcasters in Kabul have long been targets of the insurgents, who killed a journalist  in November.
content: More than a hundred journalists employed by the American government’s own radio stations remain in Afghanistan as the Taliban take power, U.S. officials and Afghan journalists said Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosa Brooks
title: Competence Is Critical for Democracy. Let’s Redefine It.
description: Skill and efficiency shouldn’t be the sole determinants of whether we consider someone competent.
content: In the last month, the Delta variant has driven up the number of new Covid cases by tens of thousands, thrown America’s pandemic response back into chaos and jeopardized the nation’s fragile economic recovery. In light of this, you might think that all of us — Republicans and Democrats alike — could at least agree on one thing: a well-functioning democratic society requires, at a bare minimum, public officials competent enough to tackle the numerous challenges we face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: The U.S. Virgin Islands face their worst surge since the start of the pandemic.
description: The popular tourist destination is now in the top 20 U.S. states and territories for cases per capita, according to a New York Times database.
content: As coronavirus cases and hospitalizations rise across the country, some areas with low vaccination rates have been hit hard, like Louisiana, Florida and Mississippi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: Clip by Clip, Showing Democracy Under Siege
description: The Times’s Visual Investigations team analyzed more than 3,000 videos to document, moment by moment, the terror of the Capitol riot.
content: On Jan 6., as rioters were attacking the U.S. Capitol, Times journalists on the Visual Investigations team were downloading as many recordings of the violence as they could find.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
title: A Week Into Taliban Rule, One City’s Glimpse of What the Future May Hold
description: In Kunduz, the new insurgent leaders said they had no quarrel with the people. But residents say they soon began instilling fear.
content: It was his first day as the Taliban-appointed mayor of Kunduz, and Gul Mohammad Elias was on a charm offensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Now Going Viral: Meeting Online Friends in Real Life
description: Marissa Meizz became a TikTok meme after her friends excluded her from a birthday party. She decided to do something about it.
content: Marissa Meizz, 23, was out to dinner with a friend in the East Village in mid-May when her phone started buzzing. She tried to silence it, but the texts kept coming. They all wanted to know: Had she seen the TikTok video?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Map: Tracking the Path of Tropical Storm Grace
description: A map showing the storm’s path through the Caribbean as it heads toward the Gulf of Mexico
content: A map showing the storm’s path through the Caribbean as it heads toward the Gulf of Mexico
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nailah Morgan and Christina Kelso
title: Taliban Occupy Afghan Presidential Palace
description: The Afghan government collapsed after the Taliban entered Kabul on Sunday. Evacuations of international diplomats and civilians have been underway at the international airport in the capital.
content: The Afghan government collapsed after the Taliban entered Kabul on Sunday. Evacuations of international diplomats and civilians have been underway at the international airport in the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Sudden Downfall in Afghanistan
description: Readers debate the wisdom and the timing of the U.S. withdrawal.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: How the Pandemic Affected Kindergarten
description: Readers discuss the effects of a lost year, child care and rethinking kindergarten’s focus on academics. Also: Transgender youths and health; Vince Lombardi and winning.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Go off script and make a no-recipe dinner: steak, potatoes and salad, or a cheesy omelet.
content: Good morning. I know I spend a lot of time telling you about recipes, about how you have to cook this incredible tangy pork noodle salad with lime and lots of herbs (above), or this bonkers good blueberry cornmeal shortbread tart. Recipes are what this newsletter is all about. Recipes are the program here, pure and simple.
source.name: The New York Times
